definition: gas/air/smell/weather/to make angry/to annoy/to get angry/vital energy/qi

sentences.english: The second yard, the ancient stone torii.
sentences.chinese: 二进院子里阔气古老的石牌坊。

sentences.english: This girl likes to put on the dog.
He had many an anecdote of the gilded youth of his time.
sentences.chinese: 他有许多他那时代的阔气少爷们的笑谈。

sentences.english: He is too extravagant with his clothes.
But he liked to impress his fellow workers.
sentences.chinese: 他喜欢在他的同事面前摆阔气。

sentences.english: In addition, our propagandists are always saying that our country is very beautiful and wealthy.
sentences.chinese: 我们的宣传也总是讲我们国家多么漂亮，多么阔气。

sentences.english: He has lost a lot of money recently but still keeps up appearances.
sentences.chinese: 最近他亏损了不少钱，但他仍然装得很阔气的样子。

sentences.english: My mother colluded in the myth of him as the swanky businessman .
sentences.chinese: 我母亲和别人串通，把他杜撰成一个阔气的商人。

sentences.english: She gave every appearance of being extremely rich.
sentences.chinese: 她处处表现得极为阔气。

sentences.english: I suppose they're trying to keep up with the Joneses.
sentences.chinese: 我猜想他们是要与别人比阔气哩。

sentences.english: He keeps rooting for a nice expensive vacation .
sentences.chinese: 他一直主张度一个阔气的假期。

sentences.english: He stays in the swankiest hotels.
sentences.chinese: 她住在豪华的旅馆里，过得真阔气。

sentences.english: As it scorns flaunting one's prosperity.
The Lord Mayor follows at the rear in his gilded coach.
sentences.chinese: 市长大人坐在他阔气的马车里在后面跟着。

definition: lit. stake a thousand pieces of gold on one throw (idiom); to throw away money recklessly/extravagant
to parade one's wealth/to be ostentatious and extravagant
ostentation/a show of extravagance/grand style/red tape
lit. to squander money like dirt (idiom)/fig. to spend money like water/extravagant
